content.raw:
The headers are not installed according to the pattern used in other ignition packages. For example, ignition-math2 installs the following:

~~~

values.title: New release would help for homebrew

content.raw: The latest tag is 0.1.0, which was when this package used ign-math2, but now the default branch uses ign-math3. The homebrew formula is used both for installing the software and for resolving dependencies for the default branch PR testing. Currently the [ignition-common formula](https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/blob/master/ignition-common.rb) depends on `ignition-math3` so that the default branch jenkins jobs will work, but building the 0.1.0 version of the formula doesn't work. It would be helpful for our homebrew package maintenance if we could make a 0.2.0 release that depends on `ign-math3`. Are there any objections?
content.html: The latest tag is 0.1.0, which was when this package used ign-math2, but now the default branch uses ign-math3. The homebrew formula is used both for installing the software and for resolving dependencies for the default branch PR testing. Currently the ignition-common formula depends on ignition-math3 so that the default branch jenkins jobs will work, but building the 0.1.0 version of the formula doesn't work. It would be helpful for our homebrew package maintenance if we could make a 0.2.0 release that depends on ign-math3. Are there any objections?

content.raw:
Ignition-common is currently a collection of several useful pieces which don't really belong in any other existing Ignition project. But many of these pieces don't have much in common among themselves either.

I suggest before we go too far and start making other libraries depend on Ignition common, we consider breaking this library into a few others, and merge some of `gazebo::util` with it. One motivation is not to bring lots of dependencies like GTS to everyone who just wants to use the plugin loader, for example.

This is a quick example of a division we could do:

New library | Classes / headers | Note | Who will use it
-------------- | -------------------- | --- | ---
"Events" | Event | | Gazebo
 | MouseEvent | | Ignition GUI
 | KeyEvent | | Ignition GUI
"Plugins" | PluginInfo | | Gazebo, GUI, Rendering, Physics, Sensors
 | PluginLoader | | =
 | PluginMacros | | =
"AudioVideo" | AudioDecoder | | Sensors
 | Video | | Sensors, GUI?
 | VideoEncoder | | Sensors, GUI?
 | OpenAL | from `gazebo::util` | Sensors
"Graphics" | Animation | animation | Rendering, Physics
 | BVHLoader | animation | =
 | KeyFrame | animation | =
 | NodeAnimation | animation | =
 | NodeTransform | animation | =
 | Skeleton | animation | =
 | SkeletonAnimation | animation | =
 | SkeletonNode | animation | =
 | Image | image | GUI, Rendering, Physics (heightmap)
 | ImageHeightmap | image | =
 | SVGLoader | image | =
 | HeightmapData | mesh | Rendering, Physics
 | ColladaExporter | mesh | =
 | ColladaLoader | mesh | =
 | Dem | mesh | =
 | GTSMeshUtils | mesh | =
 | Material | mesh | =
 | Mesh | mesh | =
 | MeshCSG | mesh | =
 | MeshExporter | mesh | =
 | MeshLoader | mesh | =
 | MeshManager | mesh | =
 | OBJLoader | mesh | =
 | STLLoader | mesh | =
 | SubMesh | mesh | =
"Util" | Base64 | 
 | Console |

 | StringUtils | 
 | System | 
 | SystemPaths | 
 | Timer |

?? | Battery |

values.title: Plugin loader could offer the option to load all known plugins

content.raw:
The plugin loader added on pull request #27 offers, among other things, interfaces to:

* add paths where to look for plugins
* load a library from a previously added path, given its filename
* list all loaded libraries

If one wants to list all the libraries available on the path, one needs to load all of them first. It would be nice if the plugin loader offered a function which automatically loads all libraries found in all registered paths.
content.html:
The plugin loader added on pull request #27 offers, among other things, interfaces to:

  • add paths where to look for plugins
  • load a library from a previously added path, given its filename
  • list all loaded libraries

If one wants to list all the libraries available on the path, one needs to load all of them first. It would be nice if the plugin loader offered a function which automatically loads all libraries found in all registered paths.

values.title: Consider having a configuration file for plugins with metadata

content.raw:
Similar to how there is a configuration file `model.config` for each model on the [model database](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/src).

This file could contain metadata about the plugin, and could be read by `PluginLoader` to offer information about the plugin before the plugin itself is loaded. Clients such as graphical interfaces (ign-gui) and websites (ign-fuel) could use this metadata to display plugin information to users.
content.html:
Similar to how there is a configuration file model.config for each model on the model database.

This file could contain metadata about the plugin, and could be read by PluginLoader to offer information about the plugin before the plugin itself is loaded. Clients such as graphical interfaces (ign-gui) and websites (ign-fuel) could use this metadata to display plugin information to users.

values.title: SystemPaths::Find file crashs if callback is not set and file does not exist

content.raw: If `SystemPaths::FindFile()` is asked to find a non-existant file and the callback has not been set using `SystemPaths::SetFindFileCallback()`, the program will crash when it attempts to call the unset callback.
content.html: If SystemPaths::FindFile() is asked to find a non-existant file and the callback has not been set using SystemPaths::SetFindFileCallback(), the program will crash when it attempts to call the unset callback.

values.title: Recommend using std::ostream& instead of enumeration for Logger

content.raw:
The current implementation of the [`ignition::common::Logger`](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/47f7af1d6a38066d8ebd5414bcd6bac053c87be4/include/ignition/common/Console.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Console.hh-125) class uses an enumeration to distinguish between whether it should print to `std::cout` or `std::cerr`. I think we can make the implementation a little nicer by forgoing that enumeration, and having `Logger` store a `std::ostream&`. This would make `Logger` more reusable, and I believe we could implement [`FileLogger`](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/47f7af1d6a38066d8ebd5414bcd6bac053c87be4/include/ignition/common/Console.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Console.hh-62) by simply inheriting `Logger` and then adding the functions that are specifically relevant to file logging. Also, `FileLogger` would be responsible for the lifecycle of the `std::ostream` that is referenced by the `Logger`.

If these changes sound good, I could implement them pretty quickly.
content.html:
The current implementation of the ignition::common::Logger class uses an enumeration to distinguish between whether it should print to std::cout or std::cerr. I think we can make the implementation a little nicer by forgoing that enumeration, and having Logger store a std::ostream&. This would make Logger more reusable, and I believe we could implement FileLogger by simply inheriting Logger and then adding the functions that are specifically relevant to file logging. Also, FileLogger would be responsible for the lifecycle of the std::ostream that is referenced by the Logger.

If these changes sound good, I could implement them pretty quickly.

values.title: Console_TEST creates a bunch of garbage directories in the home directory

content.raw:
It seems that the unit test `Console_TEST` creates a bunch of garbage directories with randomized names in the home directory of whatever user runs the test. To call this annoying would be an understatement. I haven't looked much into what exactly the test is doing, but could we either

* Have the test clear the directories after they are no longer needed

and/or

* Create the directories in an isolated directory (maybe something like `~/ign-test/`) where they will not clutter the user space? That way in the worst case scenario, the user only has to delete one directory instead of cherrypicking through the home directory to clear out the garbage?

  • Have the test clear the directories after they are no longer needed

and/or

  • Create the directories in an isolated directory (maybe something like ~/ign-test/) where they will not clutter the user space? That way in the worst case scenario, the user only has to delete one directory instead of cherrypicking through the home directory to clear out the garbage?

values.title: The use of symlinks on Windows is dubious

content.raw:
I've been grinding away at getting `ignition-common` to work properly on Windows, and there is only one last hurdle that I've encountered: symlinks. In the `UNIT_Filesystem_TEST`, we have tests called `symlink_exists` and `directory_iterator` which attempt to create symlinks and then test for their existence.

It seems that creating symlinks on Windows is not at all similar to ordinary file or directory creation, the way it is on UNIX. Creating symlinks on Windows requires any one of the following (1) disabling User Account Control [UAC], (2) configuring user settings to permit a user to create symlinks, or (3) providing administrative privileges to any application that wants to create a symlink. While this isn't an authoritative source, I found [this blog post](http://blog.rlucas.net/rants/dont-bother-with-symlinks-in-windows-7/) to be the most concise and accurate summary of what I've discovered while scouring the web.

I consider these three conditions to be extremely problematic for the following reasons:

1. Disabling UAC is a major security risk and is not something that we should even consider doing just for the sake of running some tests.

2. The way to grant users permission for creating symlinks is by enabling a `SeCreateSymbolicLinkPrivilege` setting for them, but this can only be set using `secpol.msc`, and that only works on "Professional" and "Ultimate" versions of Windows. Users who have "Home Premium" (which will be common among casual users) will not even have this option.

3. Giving administrative privileges to a test application requires manual intervention by the user, and even if that is technically possible, it would still be asking far too much to have a user trust our testing framework with administrative rights. Also, there may be office environments in which a user would not even have the ability to grant such rights anyhow.

In Microsoft's [official documentation on creating symbolic links](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/device-security/security-policy-settings/create-symbolic-links) they appear to hold a pretty firm stance that symbolic links represent a security vulnerability, so I doubt any of these conditions are going to change in the foreseeable future.

That being the case, I propose we turn off these symbolic link tests for Windows by default, since there does not appear to be a reasonable way to make it work through normal deployment. We can use a cmake variable to toggle whether those specific tests are compiled for Windows (which will be off by default), and then if someone wants to test it, they can configure cmake to turn the variable on so that those tests are included, and then they can take responsibility for meeting one of the conditions that are required to create symbolic links.

values.title: GTSMeshUtils delaunay triangulation fails on OSX

content.html:
Migrated from https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/1479/gtsmeshutils-delaunay-triangulation-fails originally reported by @iche033

There are two test failures related to Delaunay Triangulation using GTS on homebrew:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/65/testReport/(root)/GTSMeshUtils/DelaunayTriangulation/
  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/65/testReport/(root)/Results/test_ran/

While debugging the failure with a judicious use of print statements; I accidentally "fixed" the test with the following print statements in the TriangleIsHole function:

diff -r 4696c8d7d7ed src/GTSMeshUtils.cc
--- a/src/GTSMeshUtils.cc   Fri Sep 08 00:11:40 2017 +0000
+++ b/src/GTSMeshUtils.cc   Mon Sep 11 16:17:03 2017 -0700
@@ -116,10 +116,21 @@

   gts_fifo_foreach(_edgeList, (GtsFunc) Intersection, data);

+  std::cerr << "x y intersections: "
+            << xCenter << " "
+            << yCenter << " "
+            << intersections << " "
+            << intersections % 2 << std::endl;
   if (intersections % 2)
     return false;
   else
+  {
+    std::cerr << "v1 " << v1->p.x << " " << v1->p.y << ",  "
+              << "v2 " << v2->p.x << " " << v2->p.y << ",  "
+              << "v3 " << v3->p.x << " " << v3->p.y
+              << std::endl;
     return true;
+  }
 }

 //////////////////////////////////////////////////

With only one of the print statements, I see a seg-fault on homebrew at GTSMeshUtils.cc:72:

diff -r 4696c8d7d7ed src/GTSMeshUtils.cc
--- a/src/GTSMeshUtils.cc   Fri Sep 08 00:11:40 2017 +0000
+++ b/src/GTSMeshUtils.cc   Mon Sep 11 16:17:03 2017 -0700
@@ -116,10 +116,21 @@

   gts_fifo_foreach(_edgeList, (GtsFunc) Intersection, data);

+  //std::cerr << "x y intersections: "
+  //          << xCenter << " "
+  //          << yCenter << " "
+  //          << intersections << " "
+  //          << intersections % 2 << std::endl;
   if (intersections % 2)
     return false;
   else
+  {
+    std::cerr << "v1 " << v1->p.x << " " << v1->p.y << ",  "
+              << "v2 " << v2->p.x << " " << v2->p.y << ",  "
+              << "v3 " << v3->p.x << " " << v3->p.y
+              << std::endl;
     return true;
+  }
 }

 //////////////////////////////////////////////////

values.title: VideoEncoder test fails on osx due to lack of ogv encoder

content.raw:
The VideoEncoder test has been failing on homebrew for a loooooong time:

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/72/testReport/(root)/VideoEncoderTest/StartStop/

There are more clues in the console output than in the failed expectations:

~~~
65: [Err] [VideoEncoder.cc:276] Codec for[vp8] not found. Video encoding is not started.
...
65: /Users/jenkins/workspace/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/ign-common/src/VideoEncoder_TEST.cc:47: Failure
65: Value of: "ogv"
65: Expected: video.Format().c_str()
65: Which is: "mp4"
~~~

The test [explicitly asks to encode a video with type ogv](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/2f89e52e0cb54ad3b3e38c61d3a8e6766c2b9cf0/src/VideoEncoder_TEST.cc?at=disable_on_windows&fileviewer=file-view-default#VideoEncoder_TEST.cc-45), but I can confirm that this codec isn't supported by the default installation of ffmpeg on homebrew:

~~~
$ ffmpeg -i video.mp4 video.ogv
...
Automatic encoder selection failed for output stream #0:0.
Default encoder for format ogg (codec theora) is probably disabled.
Please choose an encoder manually.
Error selecting an encoder for stream 0:0
~~~

content.raw:
Starting with [build 74](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/74), the [ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64) build has been failing. It fails during `make install` due to a permissions issue:

~~~
Install the project...
-- Install configuration: "RelWithDebInfo"
Scanning dependencies of target man
Built target man
CMake Error at cmake_install.cmake:43 (file):
  file cannot create directory: /ignition/common0/ignition/common.  Maybe
  need administrative privileges.


make: *** [install] Error 1
~~~

but it is using the wrong install prefix for one of the header files: `/ignition/common0/ignition/common`. From the generated `cmake_install.cmake` in the build folder:

~~~
if("${CMAKE_INSTALL_COMPONENT}" STREQUAL "headers" OR NOT CMAKE_INSTALL_COMPONENT)
  list(APPEND CMAKE_ABSOLUTE_DESTINATION_FILES
   "/ignition/common0/ignition/common/config.hh")
  if(CMAKE_WARN_ON_ABSOLUTE_INSTALL_DESTINATION)
    message(WARNING "ABSOLUTE path INSTALL DESTINATION : ${CMAKE_ABSOLUTE_DESTINATION_FILES}")
  endif()
  if(CMAKE_ERROR_ON_ABSOLUTE_INSTALL_DESTINATION)
    message(FATAL_ERROR "ABSOLUTE path INSTALL DESTINATION forbidden (by caller): ${CMAKE_ABSOLUTE_DESTINATION_FILES}")
  endif()
file(INSTALL DESTINATION "/ignition/common0/ignition/common" TYPE FILE FILES "/Users/jenkins/workspace/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/build/include/ignition/common/config.hh")
endif()
~~~

There are other things that are installed to the correct prefix, but for some reason the config.hh header is losing its prefix. It is installed using `ign_install_includes` [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/cba80b52089e3b953a350b5bbaa6b24d00af8e5f/CMakeLists.txt?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#CMakeLists.txt-259:264).

One possible precipitating factor was my [change yesterday](https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/291) to the `ignition-math4` homebrew formula to use the `CMakeRefactor-default` branch. So now that ignition-common is finding ignition-math4, that is also using ignition-cmake on homebrew. I'll try some further testing to see if the ignition-math4 formula change is the culprit.

cc: @mxgrey @clalancette
content.html:
Starting with build 74, the ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64 build has been failing. It fails during make install due to a permissions issue:

Install the project...
-- Install configuration: "RelWithDebInfo"
Scanning dependencies of target man
Built target man
CMake Error at cmake_install.cmake:43 (file):
  file cannot create directory: /ignition/common0/ignition/common.  Maybe
  need administrative privileges.


make: *** [install] Error 1

but it is using the wrong install prefix for one of the header files: /ignition/common0/ignition/common. From the generated cmake_install.cmake in the build folder:

if("${CMAKE_INSTALL_COMPONENT}" STREQUAL "headers" OR NOT CMAKE_INSTALL_COMPONENT)
  list(APPEND CMAKE_ABSOLUTE_DESTINATION_FILES
   "/ignition/common0/ignition/common/config.hh")
  if(CMAKE_WARN_ON_ABSOLUTE_INSTALL_DESTINATION)
    message(WARNING "ABSOLUTE path INSTALL DESTINATION : ${CMAKE_ABSOLUTE_DESTINATION_FILES}")
  endif()
  if(CMAKE_ERROR_ON_ABSOLUTE_INSTALL_DESTINATION)
    message(FATAL_ERROR "ABSOLUTE path INSTALL DESTINATION forbidden (by caller): ${CMAKE_ABSOLUTE_DESTINATION_FILES}")
  endif()
file(INSTALL DESTINATION "/ignition/common0/ignition/common" TYPE FILE FILES "/Users/jenkins/workspace/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/build/include/ignition/common/config.hh")
endif()

There are other things that are installed to the correct prefix, but for some reason the config.hh header is losing its prefix. It is installed using ign_install_includes here.

One possible precipitating factor was my change yesterday to the ignition-math4 homebrew formula to use the CMakeRefactor-default branch. So now that ignition-common is finding ignition-math4, that is also using ignition-cmake on homebrew. I'll try some further testing to see if the ignition-math4 formula change is the culprit.

cc: @mxgrey @clalancette

values.title: Tinyxml2 asserts disabled in internal copy of XMLDocument::Clear

content.html:
In pull request #69, some asserts were disabled in our internal copy of tinyxml2 since they were failing on windows. From 1633785:

      // Dev notes by MXG:
      // These assertions fail when the DEBUG macro is defined. They fail invisibly on 
      // non-Windows systems because the DEBUG macro is not checking for NDEBUG, which 
      // is the standard non-Windows preprocessor token for specifying (not) debug mode.
      // Testing against tinyxml2 version 4 also triggers these asserts.
      // Testing against version 5 procuces a stack overflow, which is a much worse situation.
      // It is not clear to me whether this is an inherent issue with tinyxml2 or whether 
      // we are simply misusing it somewhere.

values.title: Race condition when running tests in parallel

content.raw:
The debbuilder job runs the tests in parallel after building and often fails during the `UNIT_Console_TEST`:

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/debbuild/job/ign-common-debbuilder/53/
* https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/debbuild/job/ign-common-debbuilder/52/
* https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/debbuild/job/ign-common-debbuilder/55/

There is probably a race condition somewhere in our testing code. I think a short-term fix is to disable parallel testing in our jenkins metadata.

cc: @\_jrivero_
content.html:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/debbuild/job/ign-common-debbuilder/52/
  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/debbuild/job/ign-common-debbuilder/55/

There is probably a race condition somewhere in our testing code. I think a short-term fix is to disable parallel testing in our jenkins metadata.

values.title: Move plugins into their own project

content.raw:
While I've been advocating for this for a while, there now seems to be a tangible motive for spinning the plugin framework of `ign-common` into its own project.

Talking with @wjwwood and @mikaelarguedas , they have expressed a serious interest in using the ignition plugin framework as a replacement for `class_loader` in ROS2. Our plugin library will provide (pending some backlogged pull requests) a number of powerful features and safety measures that are currently unobtainable in `class_loader` due to legacy design issues.

The only barrier to adoption is that the plugin framework needs to be provided as its own library, independent from `ign-common`. I think this is a reasonable and desirable change to make, and it may motivate even wider adoption of the library, going beyond the ROS and Gazebo communities.

I can easily do this right away and migrate the open plugin PRs over to a new project, but first I wanted to get a gauge of the ignition developers' feelings on this.

Our plugin library will provide (pending some backlogged pull requests) a number of powerful features and safety measures that are currently unobtainable in class_loader due to legacy design issues.

The only barrier to adoption is that the plugin framework needs to be provided as its own library, independent from ign-common. I think this is a reasonable and desirable change to make, and it may motivate even wider adoption of the library, going beyond the ROS and Gazebo communities.

I can easily do this right away and migrate the open plugin PRs over to a new project, but first I wanted to get a gauge of the ignition developers' feelings on this.

content.raw:
Looking at the `PluginLoader` implementation, we're using the `RTLD_LAZY` as the flag parameter when calling `dlopen`.  [Here's](http://tldp.org/HOWTO/Program-Library-HOWTO/dl-libraries.html) a description of the available flags.

Based on the documentation and a chat with @mxgrey, we conclude that Ignition Common doesn't have a particular preference between `RTLD_LAZY` or `RTLD_NOW`. The main implications seem to affect performance. `RTLD_NOW` front-loads some of the work when `dlopen()` is called at the cost of resolving symbols that might not be used. On the other hand, `RTLD_LAZY` returns faster from `dlopen()` but it will require to resolve the symbol the first time is really used.

To accommodate the different use cases from the Ignition Common users, we could expose the ability to choose the mode to the users. We discussed two options:

* Expose the flag at the `PluginLoader` class. All subsequent calls to `LoadLibrary()` will use the previously set flag.
* Expose the flag as a new `LoadLibrary()` parameter (possibly with a default option).
content.html:
Looking at the PluginLoader implementation, we're using the RTLD_LAZY as the flag parameter when calling dlopen. Here's a description of the available flags.

Based on the documentation and a chat with @mxgrey, we conclude that Ignition Common doesn't have a particular preference between RTLD_LAZY or RTLD_NOW. The main implications seem to affect performance. RTLD_NOW front-loads some of the work when dlopen() is called at the cost of resolving symbols that might not be used. On the other hand, RTLD_LAZY returns faster from dlopen() but it will require to resolve the symbol the first time is really used.

To accommodate the different use cases from the Ignition Common users, we could expose the ability to choose the mode to the users. We discussed two options:

  • Expose the flag at the PluginLoader class. All subsequent calls to LoadLibrary() will use the previously set flag.
  • Expose the flag as a new LoadLibrary() parameter (possibly with a default option).

content.raw: Once a mesh is loaded into the MeshManager, there is currently no API to remove / unload the mesh. So when you try to load a different mesh but with the same name, the old mesh gets returned.

content.raw:
Right now we're in an awkward state where URIs can be stored with plain blank spaces, which is disallowed by [RFC 3986](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#appendix-A) but is needed by `ign-fuel-tools`.

It would be more appropriate to support encoding / decoding of the URI, so when the URI is retrieved as a string, it wouldn't contain plain blank spaces.
content.html:
Right now we're in an awkward state where URIs can be stored with plain blank spaces, which is disallowed by RFC 3986 but is needed by ign-fuel-tools.

It would be more appropriate to support encoding / decoding of the URI, so when the URI is retrieved as a string, it wouldn't contain plain blank spaces.

content.raw:
It looks like the behavior of FreeImage for jpeg images has changed with its recent 3.18 release on homebrew. I noticed this due to a regression in gazebo's `Image_TEST`, which uses `wood.jpg`, though the `Image_TEST` in ign-common doesn't show this regression because it uses `cordless_drill.png`. I'm reporting it here because this is the target of future development. We could reproduce the failure by adding a jpeg test to `Image_TEST` in this repo.

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo7-homebrew-amd64/253/testReport/(root)/ImageTest/Image/

freeimage formula updated on August 1

* https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/commit/9f999affd653e2420671c1bc7463a21069f21144

values.title: Time::Sleep always returns Time(0, 0) even if it was interrupted by a signal on Linux

content.raw:
# Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Checked the Q&A board for common solutions: http://answers.gazebosim.org
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed.
    * Checked that there is not already an Ignition package that provides the described functionality: https://ignitionrobotics.org/libs

# Description 

Inspecting the source code, I noticed that the return value of the `clock_nanosleep` call in the `Time::Sleep` method ( #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/a78c126bd44e794b7eab74f8b656e726d0f2fd76/src/Time.cc#lines-213 ) is compared against `-1` to check if the sleep was interrupted before the desired elapsed time has passed.  However, in Linux docs ( http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/clock_nanosleep.2.html ) it is explicitly stated that the return value is a positive error message. In particular, the corresponding error should be `EINTR`, that from a quick check on my Ubuntu 18.04 is equal to: 
~~~
straversaro@iiticublap103:~$ cat   /usr/include/asm-generic/errno-base.h  | grep EINTR
#define	EINTR		 4	/* Interrupted system call */
~~~
So, even if `clock_nanosleep` returns `EINTR` the return value of the Sleep is always Time(0, 0).

The same problem is afflicting the Gazebo's version of the method. 

# Steps to Reproduce
I did not attempt to reproduce the issue, but it should be reproducible by having a process sleeping for a long time, waking it with a signal before the wait period ended, and checking the return value of the `Sleep` method. 

**Expected behavior:**  

Inspecting the rest of the code, I thought that the `Sleep` method was returning the remainder of time still need to pass before the requested time was elapsed, but according to the docs it is supposed to return the "Time actually slept", so I am not really sure about what the actual expected behavior his. 

**Actual behavior:**

See "Steps to Reproduced". I did not actually reproduced the error. 

**Reproduces how often:** 

The wrong check is done always,  but when the `clock_nanosleep` is returning 0, the if is working as expected.

# Versions

ignition-common, branch gz11

# Additional Information

values.title: Port gazebo Console log size reduction to ignition

content.html:
ign-common and gazebo use similar color console mechanisms, but the log files can be very large. A gazebo pull request helped reduce it a bit, but it hasn't yet been merged to ign-common.

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/commits/10c16cfc0035144e4b523716615fe8fe516223e1
diff --git a/gazebo/common/Console.cc b/gazebo/common/Console.cc
--- a/gazebo/common/Console.cc
+++ b/gazebo/common/Console.cc
@@ -77,9 +77,11 @@
   int index = _file.find_last_of("/") + 1;

   Console::log << "(" << Time::GetWallTime() << ") ";
-  (*this) << this->prefix
+  std::stringstream prefixString;
+  prefixString << this->prefix
     << "[" << _file.substr(index , _file.size() - index) << ":"
     << _line << "] ";
+  (*this) << prefixString.str();

   return (*this);
 }

This line seems to be a bug:

#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/db2da2c26347db7deef0e420d73aa75066c0e60d/graphics/src/NodeAnimation.cc#lines-166

Function FrameAt is to interpolate a frame between prevKey and nextKey. So the if should be like 

if (t < 0.0 || t > 1.0)
{
  ignerr << "Invalid time range\n";
  return math::Matrix4d();
}
